thread.title: Esquire says Townsman is one of best new restaurants in America - Food
thread.title_full: Esquire says Townsman is one of best new restaurants in America - Food

author: boston.com
title: Esquire says Townsman is one of best new restaurants in America - Food
text:
Esquire released its annual “ Best New Restaurants in America ” list on Tuesday, and out of the 14 restaurants, one new dining spot in Boston made the cut: Townsman.
Townsman, which opened in February on Kingston Street near the Rose Kennedy Greenway, is a brasserie-inspired restaurant. According to Esquire , chef-owner Matt Jennings prides himeslf on New England-inspired dishes, from the expected, clam chowder, brown bread, and oysters, to the creative, beef cheek and smoked apple pierogi, foie gras with blueberries, and bluefish pâté.
“Here I was at chef Matt Jennings’s Townsman, in Boston, experiencing the torrid, too-short love affair of a New England summer,” John Devore wrote in his review in Esquire .
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below The full article is expected to hit stands Oct. 20.
Gallery: 21 foods that scream New England
Previous -- of -- Next Lobster is insanely popular throughout New England, but especially in Maine. Lobster is a $300 million industry there, where 104 million pounds of lobster were caught in 2011, according to visitmaine.net. Paul Brighton / Shutterstock Previous -- of -- Next Steamed clams—or “steem-ahs”—are as common as the summer sunshine in these parts. Don’t forget the cups of broth and hot, melted butter! These clams hail from the Brighton Fish Company. Pat Greenhouse / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Ah, maple syrup. What would our pancakes, French toast, and waffles do without it? It’s also excellent in ice cream (more on that later). Vermont, the nation’s leading producer of maple syrup, is the perfect place to buy some. These jars were spotted at Marvin's sugarhouse in Johnson, Vermont. Ian Thomas Jansen-Lonnquist for The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next You can eat cranberries in sauce, juice, pie, chutney, wine ... the list goes on and on. This native New England berry was first farmed on Cape Cod in 1816, and it is a top crop in Massachusetts (second only to Wisconsin). Courtesy of Plymouth Farmer’s Market Previous -- of -- Next Few New England sandwiches are as beloved as the lobster roll. How do you like yours? Hot or cold? Naked or with mayonnaise? This one is from the Ipswich Clambake Food Truck. Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next New England clam chowder is second to none. Get a cup at the Union Oyster House, America’s oldest restaurant, which has been serving chowder and other seafood to New Englanders since 1826. Flickr / jpellgen Previous -- of -- Next Many New Englanders have the shared experience of eating beans and hot dogs with this brown bread from a can on Saturday nights growing up, according to nostalgic-filled posts on yankeemagazine.com. You can find a recipe online or look in the grocery store for a can of B&M bread. Kayana Szymczak / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The Vermont maple creemee—soft-serve ice cream infused with maple syrup and/or maple sugar—is a Green Mountain State tradition. This creemee stand photo was taken in Burlington, Vermont. Flickr / Scott Smithson Previous -- of -- Next NECCO, the New England Confectionery Company, is the oldest continually operating candy company in America. It has been making those famous wafers since 1847. The original eight flavors were chocolate, licorice, cinnamon, lemon, lime, orange, wintergreen, and clove. Charles Krupa / AP Previous -- of -- Next “Stuffies” are well-known across New England and especially popular in Rhode Island. The meat of a quahog, or hard clam, is mixed with bread or cornmeal along with spices, then it’s baked right in its shell. Flickr / Christina B Castro Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next The whoopie pie is Maine’s official state treat. You’ll find the chocolate cakes stuffed with frosting in supermarkets, restaurants, convenience stores, gift shops, and even gas stations across the state. And there’s a festival dedicated to the treat each year in Dover-Foxcroft, Maine. Kayana Szymczak / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Grape-Nuts ice cream may sound odd to some, but it’s not to New Englanders. The crunchy, creamy treat is made by combining ice cream and Grape-Nuts breakfast cereal. This cone is from Dorman’s Dairy Dream in Thomaston, Maine. Flickr / tiny banquet committee Previous -- of -- Next Rhode Island is famous for its Del’s Frozen Lemonade, a refreshing concoction of crushed ice, lemons, and sugar. Flickr / Juli Previous -- of -- Next Is it summer if you don’t stop by a New England clam shack and order a plate of fried clams? We think not. These clams hail from Redd’s in Rozzie in Roslindale. Kayana Szymczak / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Boston’s nickname “Beantown” refers to the once-popular regional dish of baked beans. Boston baked beans are comprised of dried navy beans baked slowly with molasses and salt pork. It was traditionally served on Saturday nights in Colonial times, according to visitnewengland.com. Charlie Mahoney Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Next time you’re in Rhode Island, try its famous coffee milk—the official state drink. This drink is created by adding coffee syrup to milk. Flickr / spablab Previous -- of -- Next The blueberry is the official state berry of Maine, and it’s an important part of the state’s heritage. The mighty berry inspires many festivals each year. Shaelan Donovan / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana in New Haven, Connecticut is one of the oldest continually run pizzerias in the country, and it’s famous for its white clam pizza. It was founded in 1925 and now has locations across Connecticut, in Yonkers, New York, and it’s coming this fall to Chestnut Hill. David Lyon / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The hermit bar, a spicy fruit bar, is rumored to have begun in New England. The treat got its name from its ability to keep for long periods. Sailors would pack them away “like hermits,” to snack on during long trips at sea, reports goodhousekeeping.com. Matthew Mead / AP Previous -- of -- Next Moxie is a soda invented by Dr. Augustin Thompson who was born in Union, Maine. The state hosts an annual Moxie Festival, which includes Moxie recipe contests like the one a local diner worker is holding in this photo. The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next They’re a staple at birthday parties across New England: Hoodsie cups. Made by Massachusetts-based Hood dairy, the 3-ounce cups of both chocolate and vanilla ice cream have been making kids smile since 1947. Here, Mike Mozart of TheToyChannel on YouTube poses with some. Flickr / Mike Mozart
